docs.lead_paragraph: One man’s battle for a heart transplant is a striking example of the best and the worst that the American health care system has to offer.

headline.seo: Uninsured and Fighting to the End for a New Heart
headline.main: A New Heart, Tangled in Red Tape
headline.print_headline: A New Heart, Tangled in Red Tape

docs.snippet: One man’s battle for a heart transplant is a striking example of the best and the worst that the American health care system has to offer.

docs.lead_paragraph: Maureen Dowd reminds us that pseudonyms have a noble history.
docs.snippet: Maureen Dowd reminds us that pseudonyms have a noble history.

docs.lead_paragraph: The national debate on health care tends to focus on providing coverage to people who do not have insurance. But a study released Monday by the Center for Health Policy Research at the University of California, Los Angeles, underscores the limits of the current system in protecting even insured people from the financial risk of being sick. The report, ''The State of Health Insurance in California,'' found that more than 2.2 million of the state's adults -- almost one in seven working-age Californians -- said they had medical debt. And two-thirds of those said they incurred the debt despite having health insurance.
docs.abstract: Center for Health Policy Research at University of California Los Angeles report underscores limits of current system in protecting even insured people from financial risk of being sick; finds that 2.2 million of California's adults say they have medical debt and two-thirds of those say they incurred debt despite having health insurance; graph (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The White House was evidently listening when Senator Michael B. Enzi of Wyoming delivered the weekly Republican radio and Internet address Saturday. And the White House spokesman, Robert Gibbs, did not like what he heard about health care from Mr. Enzi, who is supposed to be part of bipartisan talks. ''Senator Enzi's clearly turned over his cards on bipartisanship and decided that it's time to walk away from the table,'' Mr. Gibbs said Monday.
docs.abstract: Republican Sen Michael B Enzi says current Democratic proposals about health care reform will raid Medicare and limit or deny care based on age or disability of patients; says proposal will insert Washington bureaucrat in relationship between doctor and patient; Democrats dispute assertion; White House is annoyed because Enzi is supposed to be part of bipartisan talks; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Taking an enemy-of-my-enemy approach, two challengers to Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania plan to get together Wednesday night for a public forum on health care. Representative Joe Sestak, above left, a Democrat who is challenging Mr. Specter in the Senate primary next spring, invited former Representative Patrick J. Toomey, above right, the likely Republican nominee for the seat, to a town-hall-style meeting. It will be held on Mr. Toomey's home turf in Allentown, at Muhlenberg College. Mr. Specter was not invited.
docs.abstract: Rep Joe Sestak, Democrat challenging Sen Arlen Specter in Pennsylavania Senate primary in 2010, invites Patrick J Toomey, likely Republican challenger, to town-hall style meeting to discuss health care reform; photos (S)
